predictions: Zully Broussard donated a kidney to a stranger, initiating a chain of six kidney transplants via paired donations at California Pacific Medical Center. Using MatchGrid software by David Jacobs, matches were made in three weeks, enabling incompatible donor-recipient pairs to receive compatible kidneys.

Since its 1996 debut, Major League Soccer (MLS) has grown significantly, expanding from 10 to 20 teams, increasing attendance, and securing a $700 million TV deal. Despite early financial losses and challenges, MLS now attracts international stars and young talent, aiming to become a top sport in the U.S.

French striker Bafetimbi Gomis collapsed during Swansea's match against Tottenham but is now "feeling well." Known for a history of fainting due to low blood pressure, he attributed this episode to stress over his father's health. Gomis reassured fans and spent the night in hospital as a precaution.

World No.1 golfer Rory McIlroy threw his 3-iron into a lake in frustration after a poor shot at the WGC Cadillac Championship. He finished with a 70, leaving him one-under and eight shots behind leader JB Holmes. Adam Scott is three shots off the lead at six-under.

A Pennsylvania community is searching for 13-year-old Cayman Naib, who went missing Wednesday after receiving an email about overdue homework. Hundreds are volunteering in the search, using geo-spatial tracking and the Civil Air Patrol. His family appeals for him to return, assuring him of forgiveness.

After Curt Schilling tweeted congratulations to his daughter on her college acceptance, she was subjected to vile and threatening messages on Twitter. Schilling tracked down the offenders, leading to consequences for them. The incident highlights the importance of online accountability and the role of protective parenting.

Two American women were arrested for carving initials into Rome's Colosseum, facing fines for aggravated damage. This reflects a trend of tourists disrespecting historic sites, including vandalism at the Colosseum, nude photos at Cambodia's Angkor complex, and inappropriate acts at Egypt's pyramids and Peru's Machu Picchu.

Prince and 3rdEyeGirl are bringing their Hit & Run Tour to the U.S. for the first time, starting with a show on March 14 in Louisville, Kentucky, hometown of drummer Hannah Welton. Tickets go on sale March 9. The venue is yet to be announced, and part of the proceeds will support local charities.

A terrorist attack at a bar in Bamako, Mali, killed five people—including French and Belgian citizens—and wounded eight others. The jihadist group al-Murabitun claimed responsibility, citing retaliation for a leader's death. Authorities are interrogating suspects amid ongoing conflicts with Islamist militants in Mali's north.

Manchester United's Jonny Evans and Newcastle's Papiss Cisse were charged by the FA for allegedly spitting at each other during a match. Both face potential six-game bans. Evans denies spitting; Cisse apologized. Former players criticized their actions as unacceptable and disgusting.

On March 10, 2015, CNN Student News features international stories from Italy, Russia, the UAE, and the Himalayas, including a solar-powered plane's global flight, mysterious craters in Asia, and unique views of Mount Everest. Viewers can access the transcript and request a Roll Call mention by submitting their school details.

Nine foreign workers—including Filipinos, an Austrian, a Czech, a Ghanaian, and a Bangladeshi—were kidnapped by ISIS-linked militants during an attack on Libya's Al-Ghani oil field, which was set on fire. Authorities are seeking their release amid escalating threats to foreign oil workers in Libya.

Wichita high school principal Sherman Padgett was initially reluctant when student Emily Jones asked him to hold a bucket, fearing a prank. When he agreed, students filled it with notes of appreciation, thanking him for his impact. The gesture moved Padgett deeply, affirming his dedication to his work.

Comic book artist Norman Lee, known for his work with Marvel and DC Comics titles like "Wolverine Annual" and "Supergirl," went missing while snorkeling off Grand Cayman Island. The search has become a recovery mission due to strong currents. Tributes from friends and colleagues are flooding in for the 47-year-old.

On March 9, 2015, CNN Student News covers anniversaries of historic events: the Selma civil rights march, the missing Malaysia Airlines flight, and International Women's Day, plus the mixed U.S. unemployment report. Viewers can access the transcript and request a Roll Call mention by commenting with school details.

Jessie Usher will star in "Independence Day 2" as the son of Will Smith's character, alongside Liam Hemsworth and returning Jeff Goldblum. Directed by Roland Emmerich, the sequel releases June 24, 2016, nearly 20 years after the original.

Former U.S. Vice President Walter Mondale, 87, was released from the Mayo Clinic after being treated for influenza, hospital officials said. Mondale served under President Jimmy Carter and later ran for president in 1984, choosing Geraldine Ferraro as his historic running mate. His wife died last year.

Kyle Waring from Massachusetts is selling Boston snow online at ShipSnowYo.com, offering 6-pound insulated boxes for $89 to customers outside the Northeast. He has filled over 133 orders, capitalizing on Boston's record snowfall. Initially shipping snow in bottles, he switched to styrofoam boxes to prevent melting.

Refugee women in Jordan, like Farah, are rebuilding their lives by becoming breadwinners and starting small businesses with support from the Near East Foundation. Empowered by vocational skills, financial literacy, and social networks, they challenge cultural norms. Aid agencies must go beyond immediate aid to empower these women, advocating for their rights and protection.

Real Madrid's 1-0 loss to Athletic Bilbao allows Barcelona to potentially lead La Liga. Coach Ancelotti is concerned about his team's lack of goals. Bayern Munich extended their Bundesliga lead with a 3-1 win over Hannover. PSG beat Lens 4-1 to temporarily top Ligue 1.

A 40-year-old man was arrested in Sumoto city, Japan, for fatally stabbing five neighbors—three women aged 59, 76, and 84, and two men aged 62 and 82. The victims lived nearby and shared the same surname as the suspect; it's unclear if they are related.

A suicide car bomber targeted a police vehicle in Lashkar Gah, the capital of Afghanistan's Helmand province, killing seven people and injuring 23 others, mostly civilians including children. The attack occurred around 6 p.m. in the Bolan area. The attacker's identity and motive remain unknown.

Pakistan's highest court ordered the release of Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, the alleged mastermind of the 2008 Mumbai attacks that killed over 160 people, calling his detention illegal. India strongly objected, summoning Pakistan's high commissioner. Lakhvi, a Lashkar-e-Taiba leader, had previously been granted bail, sparking criticism in India.

A white DeKalb County police officer fatally shot an unarmed African-American man who was running naked and allegedly acting erratically in an Atlanta apartment complex. The man charged at the officer, who fired two shots. The case is under independent investigation, highlighting concerns over police shootings and mental health training.

A viral photo shows a weasel hitching a ride on a flying woodpecker near London. Photographer Martin Le-May captured the image in Hornchurch Country Park. The weasel attacked the bird but eventually fell off. Experts say such attacks are possible as weasels are aggressive hunters with high metabolisms.

Fans are selling bags of air allegedly from Kanye West concerts on eBay, with one auction reaching $60,000 before removal. Copycat listings and gag items have emerged. Meanwhile, Kanye's Yeezy 750 Boost sneakers are reselling at high prices on eBay, contrary to his desire for them to be affordable.

The Delta Air Lines crew of the plane that skidded off the runway at LaGuardia Airport reported brake issues during landing, noting no deceleration despite auto brakes set to "max." The aircraft sustained significant damage; 23 passengers had minor injuries. The NTSB is investigating the cause.

Pakistan renamed 107 schools after students killed in the December Taliban attack on Peshawar's Army Public School, where militants killed 145 people, including 132 children. The gesture honors their bravery. Authorities arrested a suspect accused of commanding the attack.

The Salvation Army in South Africa used the viral "dress" debate to raise awareness about domestic violence. An ad features a bruised woman in a white and gold dress with the caption, "Why is it so hard to see black and blue?" highlighting the often-overlooked signs of abuse.

NASCAR reinstated driver Kurt Busch under indefinite probation after lifting his suspension. Busch was suspended when a court found probable domestic violence against his ex-girlfriend, but no charges were filed. He's eligible to compete immediately after completing NASCAR's reinstatement program and behavioral assessments.

An interim report on Flight MH370's disappearance reveals confusion and delays by air traffic controllers and radar operators; over five hours passed before a distress signal was sent, more before search began. Miscommunications and agency failures hindered response, potentially costing valuable search time.

A ferry capsized near Sittwe, Myanmar, after being struck by a large wave during bad weather, leaving 21 dead and 21 missing. At least 167 people were rescued. Ferry accidents are common in the region, with previous deadly incidents in Myanmar and neighboring Bangladesh.

A Myanmar warplane dropped a bomb on a sugarcane field in China's Yunnan province, killing four civilians and wounding nine, according to state media. China deployed fighter jets along the border, summoned Myanmar's ambassador, and demanded an investigation as Myanmar battles ethnic separatist rebels near the border.

The article outlines five common mistakes in online self-diagnosis: using unreliable sources, trusting unverified forum advice, letting emotions skew judgment, not sharing online findings with doctors, and delaying professional care. It advises using reputable websites and communicating openly with healthcare professionals.

Erich Nowsch Jr., 19, was indicted for the fatal shooting of neighbor Tammy Meyers, 44, in Clark County, Nevada. Following a confrontation during a driving lesson, Meyers was shot outside her home. Nowsch faces murder charges but claims self-defense. The driver of the other car has not been found.

The article discusses strained race relations due to recent events involving police and minority communities. It suggests improving relations through community engagement, integrating officers into neighborhoods via foot patrols and shared activities, and fostering mutual trust to address historical biases and build safer, united communities.

A North Korean diplomat, Son Young Nam, was caught with 27 kg of undeclared gold worth $1 million at Dhaka airport. Bangladeshi customs, acting on a tip, found 170 gold bars in his luggage after he resisted search. The North Korean ambassador apologized, and the diplomat has since left the country.

After a car crash into a Utah river killed her mother, toddler Lily was found alive after 14 hours, hanging upside down in the car. Her father, Deven Trafny, says she’s doing great and he feels blessed. A fisherman spotted the car, leading to her rescue.

A medical helicopter carrying three EagleMed LLC employees crashed near Eufaula, Oklahoma, Thursday night while en route from Tulsa to McAlester; the FAA is investigating. Earlier this week, an Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed off Florida's Panhandle, killing all 11 aboard; recovery efforts are ongoing.

Monohm's Runcible is a circular "anti-smartphone" challenging the dominance of rectangular screens. The device aims to reduce digital distractions by reimagining how screen shapes influence user behavior, offering an alternative experience and questioning the status quo of rectangular technology.

The official Star Wars universe is introducing its first gay character, Moff Mors, a capable but flawed Imperial official who is a lesbian, in the upcoming novel "Lords of the Sith," as confirmed by Shelly Shapiro, editor of "Star Wars" books at Del Rey Books.

Suicide bombers attacked a Christian community in Lahore, Pakistan, killing at least 14 and wounding dozens. The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility, warning of more attacks until Sharia law is implemented. Officials condemned the violence, highlighting the ongoing threats faced by religious minorities in Pakistan.

A massive IRS impersonation scam has defrauded over 3,000 victims of more than $15 million since 2013. Scammers, posing as IRS agents with personal information, threaten victims with arrest or legal action unless they pay immediately. Authorities advise hanging up if contacted.

The article argues that the GOP's letter to Iran undermining Obama's policy is extraordinary but not unique; past figures like Kennedy and Nixon interfered with presidential foreign policy. Foreign policy often becomes partisan, challenging executive authority—inevitable in a system with limited executive power and party competition.

Pope Francis told Mexican network Televisa he expects his papacy to be brief, possibly ending in a few years. He appreciates Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI's resignation for opening the door to future retirements. He announced a "Jubilee of Mercy" starting in December 2015.

Actor Ashton Kutcher lamented on Facebook about the lack of diaper changing tables in men's public restrooms, sparking discussions among parents. His post received over 230,000 comments, with many praising him for highlighting the issue and advocating for gender equality in parenting responsibilities.

Spain's Caminito del Rey, once "the world's most dangerous path," reopens March 26 after reconstruction. The trail, featuring a boardwalk 100 meters above the Guadalhorce River, was closed due to fatalities. Now safer, the 7.7 km route is free for six months; booking at Caminitodelrey.info is required.

Isaac Herzog, leading the Zionist Union, challenges Netanyahu in Israeli elections. Despite less charisma, he promises social reform, social justice, and to restart peace talks with Palestinians. Vowing to prevent nuclear Iran by working with partners, he believes his prominent political legacy destines him to lead Israel.

Hundreds of thousands protested across Brazil, demanding President Dilma Rousseff's impeachment over economic troubles and a massive corruption scandal at Petrobras, the state oil company. Although Rousseff hasn't been accused, she chaired Petrobras when alleged bribes occurred. The protests, organized by opposition groups, may hinder her ability to govern.

Turkish officials detained 16 Indonesians who admitted planning to cross into Syria, Indonesia's foreign ministry said. The group—one man, four women, three girls, eight boys—was stopped in Gaziantep. Indonesia is sending a security team to investigate. This group is separate from another missing group of 16 Indonesians.

An attack on a Tamil news station over a program about a traditional necklace underscores growing threats to free speech in India. Censorship of books, films, and media due to religious sensitivities reflects increasing intolerance toward differing opinions, undermining the country's constitutional guarantee of freedom of expression.

In 2001, Serena Williams faced racial abuse at Indian Wells after Venus withdrew from their semifinal, leading to match-fixing accusations. Despite winning the final, Serena boycotted the event for 14 years. She returned in 2015, "following her heart," while Venus and their father continue the boycott.

Anti-racism organization Kick It Out reports a 35% increase in fans reporting abusive behavior in football, largely due to its anonymous reporting app. The app empowers fans to self-police, leading to more investigations by the Football Association and highlighting its impact in tackling discrimination.

After an 18-year-old was charged for urging a friend's suicide via texts, lawyer Lisa Green urges parents to prepare legally for their teens. She recommends having a criminal defense lawyer ready and educating both themselves and their children about legal rights to navigate potential issues.

Photographer Ignacio Evangelista's "After Schengen" project captures Europe's abandoned border checkpoints—ghostly remnants of pre-Schengen times when travel meant passports and delays. His images reflect on the transformation to open borders, highlighting political and personal impacts, and the lingering atmosphere of these former fortifications.

Daniel Ricciardo reflects on the unforgiving nature of Formula One, where mechanical issues can overshadow driver skill. After being disqualified from second place in last year's Australian Grand Prix due to a fuel flow violation, he seeks redemption at this year's race, energized by his home crowd's support.

Disney's live-action "Cinderella" opened with $70.1 million, exceeding expectations and surpassing last year's "Maleficent." Directed by Kenneth Branagh and starring Lily James and Cate Blanchett, it received strong reviews (83% on Rotten Tomatoes). Liam Neeson's "Run All Night" had a weak debut. "Kingsman" crossed $100 million domestically.

Harper Lee, the 88-year-old author of "To Kill a Mockingbird," is publishing "Go Set a Watchman." Despite concerns about her ability to consent, Alabama officials confirmed she wants to publish. The book, written before her classic, was found by her lawyer and releases in July.

Navy veteran Vanessa Hicks photographed a sailor cradling his baby in an American flag. Critics labeled it flag desecration per the U.S. Flag Code, but many defended it as patriotic. Despite receiving threats, Hicks continues to create similar images, highlighting their symbolic significance.

Professor Candida Moss, a New Testament expert, answers viewer questions from CNN's "Finding Jesus" series. She discusses the significance of the number 40 in the Bible, the relationship between Jesus and John the Baptist, DNA tests on relics, extra-biblical references to John, and the origins of the Lord's Prayer.

The Apple Watch offers benefits like discreetly tracking information without appearing rude, but research highlights downsides. Users may develop compulsive checking habits, experience "phantom device effects," become overly focused on personal data, leading to anxiety and self-obsession, raising privacy concerns, and ushering in the "internet of me."

Police raided Robert Durst's Houston home after he was charged with first-degree murder in the 2000 killing of Susan Berman. Durst, arrested in New Orleans on drug and weapons charges, is accused of killing Berman because she was a witness to a crime. He denies involvement and awaits trial.

The Southern Poverty Law Center reports that U.S. hate groups declined by 17% between 2013 and 2014, reaching their lowest level since 2005. While organized groups decrease, hate may be shifting online, and lone actors pose increasing concerns for domestic terrorism.

Rev. Fred Craddock, an influential preacher known for his inductive, storytelling style, died at 86 in Georgia after battling Parkinson's disease. A beloved professor at Emory's Candler School of Theology, he was among the most effective English-speaking preachers and founded the Craddock Center to aid needy children.

Last month, the State Department began automatically preserving emails from high-level officials amid controversy over Hillary Clinton's use of a private email account as Secretary of State. Clinton believed her emails were saved; Republicans seek access to her personal server to ensure all official communications are preserved.

Two more American aid workers exposed to Ebola in Sierra Leone arrived in the U.S. for monitoring, joining eight others. None are known to be infected. They had high-risk contact with a colleague now critically ill with Ebola at NIH. Monitoring protocols are in place.

Arsenal beat Manchester United 2-1 at Old Trafford to reach the FA Cup semifinals. Former United player Danny Welbeck scored the winner after Antonio Valencia's error. Angel Di María was sent off for grabbing the referee. Arsenal will face either Reading or Bradford City in the next round.

An African-American woman in Ferguson lost her car and paid $1,200 in fines due to aggressive city policies targeting black residents with excessive tickets to raise revenue. The DOJ found systemic racial discrimination in Ferguson's police and courts, leading to calls for reforms.

After canceled engagements sparked health rumors, Russian President Putin appeared in Kremlin photos on Friday. Spokesman Dmitry Peskov denied illness speculation, attributing it to "spring fever." Putin's last public appearance was Sunday; recent meetings had only still photos released, fueling the conjecture about his absence.

Paris Saint-Germain advanced to the Champions League quarterfinals on away goals after a 2-2 draw with Chelsea. Despite Zlatan Ibrahimović's early red card, PSG battled with 10 men for 90 minutes. Thiago Silva redeemed his earlier handball by scoring the decisive goal. Bayern Munich defeated Shakhtar Donetsk 7-0 to progress.

Five Chelsea football fans have been summoned to court over alleged racist actions in Paris. They were filmed blocking a black man, Souleymane S., from boarding a metro train and chanting racist slogans. Chelsea condemned the incident, suspended the fans, and they may face life bans.

Sotheby's is auctioning a $900,000 sculpture by Maurizio Cattelan that lists every defeat of the England football team from 1874 to 1998, carved into black granite. The artwork humorously highlights England's soccer losses and is on display until March 10 before being sold.

Tens of thousands rallied in Tel Aviv's "Israel Wants Change" protest organized by One Million Hands, demanding leadership change due to dissatisfaction with Prime Minister Netanyahu's handling of the two-state solution and cost of living. Former Mossad chief Meir Dagan criticized political stagnation. Despite protests, Netanyahu's Likud party remains strong in polls.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 30th Induction Ceremony is on April 18 at Cleveland's Public Hall. Inductees include Ringo Starr, Bill Withers, and Lou Reed. Presenters include Paul McCartney and Stevie Wonder. Performers like Beck and John Legend will appear. The event airs on HBO May 30.

US Air Force veteran Tairod Nathan Webster Pugh pleaded not guilty in New York to charges of attempting to support ISIS. He allegedly tried to join the group in Syria but was turned back by Turkish authorities. Investigators found extremist materials on his devices, including a letter expressing intent to defend the Islamic State.

The article argues that Silicon Valley is eliminating jobs instead of creating them, leaving millennials in low-paying, unstable positions. The digital economy replaces middle-class jobs with minimum wage and gig work lacking security. To avoid a dystopian future, we must hold tech giants accountable and challenge their practices.

Divers are recovering artifacts from the wreck of the CSS Georgia in the Savannah River, including leg irons and cannon parts. The ironclad was scuttled in 1864 without firing in battle. The recovery is part of river deepening; artifacts will be conserved for display.

Amid rising concerns over dangerous tourist driving in New Zealand's South Island, locals have been confiscating car keys from foreign drivers—a practice condemned by authorities. While only 6% of national crashes involve tourists, the rate is higher in scenic areas. Officials advocate education over vigilantism.

Tropical Cyclone Pam caused "unbelievable destruction" in Vanuatu's capital, Port Vila, leaving many homeless and in urgent need of shelter, food, and water. Relief efforts are underway amid ongoing fierce winds and rain. Pam is one of the strongest storms since Typhoon Haiyan in 2013.

In Esfahan, Iran, a vibrant Jewish community openly practices their faith, with synagogues and businesses operating alongside Muslim neighbors. Despite tensions between Iran and Israel, Iranian Jews feel at home, consider themselves Iranian, and experience religious freedom, while friends abroad often express concern.

The article argues that Israel's upcoming elections are unlikely to change policies toward Palestinians, as both Netanyahu and Herzog lack plans to end the occupation. The critical issue of Palestinian territories is ignored in the campaign, questioning Israel's democratic integrity.

A video reportedly shows three British schoolgirls crossing from Turkey into Syria last month to join ISIS. Released by Turkish TV, the footage shows them in Gaziantep near the Syrian border. Turkish authorities allege a spy from a coalition country helped them enter Syria.

Kerry Washington will star as Anita Hill and executive produce HBO's film "Confirmation," depicting the 1991 Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill Supreme Court hearings. Susannah Grant will write and executive produce, with Michael London and Janice Williams also producing. Rick Famuyiwa is in talks to direct.

The article criticizes Republicans for disrespecting President Obama, exemplified by 47 Senators sending a letter to Iran undermining his diplomacy. It cites past incidents suggesting an anti-Obama bias possibly linked to racial prejudice, and urges honorable disagreement to uphold national values and healthy political discourse.

A CNN journalist interviewed Prince Charles at his Scottish home, Birkhall, about his 10th wedding anniversary and upcoming U.S. tour. Camilla welcomed the crew but declined an interview. The couple appeared close and relaxed, offering rare glimpses into their private life before Charles ascends the throne.

After the violent arrest of African-American student Martese Johnson, which left him injured, University of Virginia student leaders organized a campus forum with police to discuss allegations of brutality and improve relations. The incident sparked protests and highlighted ongoing concerns about police use of force against African-Americans.

Kelly Gissendaner, on death row in Georgia for her husband's murder, transformed herself through theological studies and ministry in prison. She became a source of hope and guidance to others. Faith leaders urge Governor Nathan Deal to intervene and commute her sentence, emphasizing her redemption and advocating for mercy.

During Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's trial, police officers testified about the intense 2013 Watertown shootout with him and his brother Tamerlan. Tamerlan was killed after being shot and run over by Dzhokhar, who escaped but was later captured hiding in a boat, a key piece of trial evidence.

An Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed off the Florida Panhandle during a training mission in heavy fog, killing all 11 aboard—seven Marines and four National Guard members. The military shifted from rescue to recovery, focusing on retrieving the wreckage and bodies. Investigations into the cause are underway.

After the deadly attack on Tunis's Bardo Museum that killed 23 people, including 19 tourists, Tunisia is investigating. Two suspects, trained in Libya, were identified; nine arrests were made. ISIS claimed responsibility. Families of attackers expressed shock, noting no prior signs of extremism.

Ferguson residents are initiating a recall of Mayor James Knowles following a DOJ report alleging systemic racism in the city's government and police. This move comes after the resignations of the police chief and city manager, and the shooting of two officers during protests over Michael Brown's death.

The murder of 20-year-old Ozgecan Aslan, who resisted a sexual assault before being killed by a bus driver, sparked nationwide protests in Turkey over women's safety. Her father believes her death awakened the nation. The family plans to create a rehabilitation center for male abusers to promote change.

Lindsey Vonn secured her 65th World Cup win in the super-G at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, taking the lead in super-G standings before the finals. She aims for titles in both super-G and downhill. Meanwhile, Kjetil Jansrud clinched the men's Super-G title in Norway and trails Marcel Hirscher in the overall standings.

The article highlights child sex trafficking in the U.S., where victims are treated as criminals and perpetrators escape serious punishment. Two bills, JVTA and SETT, aim to support victims and strengthen laws against traffickers. The authors urge action to end this modern-day slavery.

Following a deadly attack at Tunisia's Bardo Museum that killed 23 people, a global social media campaign "#IWillComeToTunisia" emerged to support the critical tourism industry. People worldwide pledge to visit, using hashtags like #JeSuisBardo, showing solidarity against fear and terrorism threatening Tunisia's economy.

Former Wimbledon champion Marion Bartoli hinted on Twitter about a possible return to tennis after retiring in 2013 due to injuries. Jimmy Connors advised her to be fully committed if she comes back. Other stars like Martina Hingis and Jennifer Capriati have also made comebacks.

Actress Liza Minnelli, 68, has entered rehab for substance abuse, her spokesman said, noting she has valiantly battled addictions over the years and seeks treatment when needed. She is making excellent progress at an undisclosed facility. Minnelli won an Oscar in 1973 for "Cabaret."

Zaur Dadayev, the main suspect in Boris Nemtsov's murder, retracted his confession, claiming torture and threats to his family. Human rights activists who reported this face legal action for "interfering" with the investigation. Amnesty International condemned the move, raising concerns over the fairness of the probe.

Ferguson seeks a new police chief to rebuild trust after Michael Brown's death and a critical DOJ report. Sanford's Chief Cecil Smith, who restored community relations after Trayvon Martin's killing, suggests empathy and engagement are key. Officials agree the new chief must address cultural issues and improve police-community relations.

March Madness, the NCAA basketball tournament, gives players from smaller schools a chance to shine nationally and boost their pro prospects. Bryce Drew's famous 1998 Valparaiso shot exemplifies this impact. Agents and coaches note the tournament highlights talent beyond traditional powerhouses, revealing "diamonds" in lesser-known programs.

Google CFO Patrick Pichette resigned to spend time with his wife, highlighting challenges in achieving work/life balance. His departure raises questions about the attainability of this balance, especially for average workers and women pressured to "have it all." Real balance is difficult amid corporate demands and economic disparities.

A.J. Pero, drummer for Twisted Sister, died at 55 of an apparent heart attack. Found on his tour bus while touring with Adrenaline Mob, he was taken to a hospital where he died. Bandmates expressed profound sadness. Pero joined Twisted Sister in 1982 and was known for "We're Not Gonna Take It."

Mexican wrestler Hijo del Perro Aguayo (Pedro Aguayo Ramirez), 35, died after collapsing during a match with Rey Mysterio in Tijuana. He was kicked, slumped against the ropes, and later died despite medical efforts. His death prompted grief and an investigation into possible manslaughter.

New Zealand police disclosed a blackmail threat to poison infant formula with 1080 unless the government halts its use for pest control. Anonymous letters with contaminated samples were sent to dairy giant Fonterra. Officials assure products are safe but urge vigilance, labeling the threat as "eco-terrorism."

After SAE fraternity members were filmed singing a racist chant, the University of Oklahoma severed ties. SAE has faced prior controversies involving hazing, member deaths, and numerous health and safety violations since 2010. These issues have led to suspensions, high insurance costs, and difficulty establishing new chapters.

Superman, Wonder Woman, and Archie Andrews have unveiled new looks. Superman now wears a t-shirt and jeans with shorter hair; Wonder Woman has pants, a turtleneck, and body armor; Archie adopts a modern style ahead of his TV show. Comic fans will have much to adjust to.

Benjamin Netanyahu won a clear victory in Israel's election, defying polls predicting a tight race or a lead for Isaac Herzog. Flawed polling methods and Netanyahu's strategic rightward shift, which drew votes from other right-wing parties, contributed to his unexpected success.

An upcoming HBO documentary titled "Montage of Heck," directed by Brett Morgen, provides an intimate portrayal of Nirvana's Kurt Cobain. Featuring interviews with family, Courtney Love, and Krist Novoselic, it includes a 12-minute unreleased acoustic track. The film premieres on HBO on May 4.

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry stated that gaps remain in nuclear talks with Iran ahead of a March 24 deadline. Despite progress, he emphasized the need for the right deal to prevent Iran from obtaining nuclear weapons, a goal shared by the P5+1 nations.

Eleven service members—seven Marines and four Louisiana National Guard members—died in a Black Hawk helicopter crash off Florida's coast. They were dedicated professionals who served in Iraq, Afghanistan, and during hurricanes. The article honors their service, achievements, and the families they left behind.

Republicans and some Democrats argue that the Obama administration's nuclear deal with Iran is a treaty requiring Senate approval. The administration asserts it's a nonbinding agreement, not necessitating congressional consent. This dispute highlights a constitutional debate over executive authority versus legislative oversight in foreign agreements.

Jeremy Clarkson, presenter of "Top Gear," was suspended by the BBC after allegedly hitting a producer. Upcoming episodes are postponed. Fans have petitioned for his reinstatement, while others call for his dismissal. Clarkson has faced prior controversies. "Top Gear" is watched by millions globally.

At Milan Fashion Week, Dolce & Gabbana dedicated their fall collection to mothers ("mamma"), showcasing feminine dresses and skirts with roses, lace, and embroidered phrases like "I love you, mamma." Models walked the runway with their children, and a tableau of mothers and daughters served as the backdrop.

An ISIS video shows Israeli Arab Mohamed Musallam being executed by a child soldier; ISIS claims he was an Israeli spy, but Israeli officials and his family deny this. His family says he was recruited by ISIS, realized his mistake, tried to return home, but was captured and killed.

Following the shooting of two police officers and the police chief's resignation after a damning Justice Department report on racist policing, Ferguson exemplifies nationwide issues of racial bias and police militarization. The article urges reforms: diversify police forces, end militarization, and implement community policing to prevent further unrest.

Two Chinese men, Han (30) and Zhang (23), were sentenced to eight and six years in prison for selling military intelligence, including photos of China's first aircraft carrier, to foreign spies. Recruited via WeChat by individuals posing as journalists, they took sensitive photos and passed them on.

Melissa Benoist stars as Supergirl in CBS's upcoming "Supergirl" series, with first-look photos released. The costume, designed by Colleen Atwood, updates the classic look. The show features Kara Zor-El (Benoist) and boasts a cast including Calista Flockhart, Mehcad Brooks, and others, with production starting in Los Angeles.

The article criticizes Republican senators' letter to Iran and Hillary Clinton's email handling. Though both began with legitimate concerns, their actions worsened political polarization by creating divisive issues, exemplifying "wooden-headedness"—stubbornly sticking to misguided paths—and diminishing hopes for better politics.

Wyatt, a 12-year-old who lost his right arm as a baby, is receiving a custom electronic prosthetic from University of Central Florida students using 3-D printing. Their group, Limbitless Solutions, creates personalized electronic arms for children, enabling new abilities and boosting confidence.

The article examines gender roles in household labor, noting that women often handle more domestic work despite working full-time. Same-sex couples tend to share tasks more equitably. The author urges men to actively promote equality by sharing chores and becoming role models for fair relationships.

Larry David's Broadway debut "Fish in the Dark" is successful but faces criticism for stereotypical portrayal of a Hispanic maid. Similarly, an all-Asian production of "Show Boat" was canceled over racial insensitivity concerns. These cases highlight challenges of race and representation in theater amid increasing diversity.

Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson surprised audiences at Valentino's Paris Fashion Week show by reprising their "Zoolander" roles as Derek Zoolander and Hansel. They walked the runway in character to promote "Zoolander 2," set for release in February 2016.

The University of Oklahoma expelled two students and disbanded the Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity after a video showed members chanting racist slurs referencing lynching. The university plans to hire a vice president for diversity. Apologies were issued by the students involved and the fraternity's alumni.

Jeremy Clarkson, a popular but controversial BBC presenter, allegedly assaulted a producer over a lack of hot food. Despite his misbehavior, fans support him, boosting his popularity. The article examines why celebrities like Clarkson thrive on controversy and maintain fan loyalty despite misconduct.

After a racist fraternity video surfaced at the University of Oklahoma, President David Boren swiftly condemned the students, severed ties with the fraternity, and expelled two students. His decisive actions exemplify moral leadership in confronting racism and highlight the importance of addressing deeper societal biases.

A Palestinian man rammed his car into a cyclist and four Israeli border police in Jerusalem, injuring them. Authorities are treating it as a terror attack. The suspect was shot and arrested. Hamas praised the attack as a response to Israeli actions. The incident reflects ongoing regional tensions.

London's National Gallery has banned selfie sticks, joining institutions like the Smithsonian and MoMA. Mar Dixon, creator of #MuseumSelfie Day, supports the ban, stating that while photos are cherished memories, selfie sticks invade personal space and pose risks to art and visitors inside museums.

The article criticizes the Republican-controlled Congress for threatening to shut down the Department of Homeland Security to roll back the President's immigration actions, risking national security and disrupting services. It argues that Republicans are prioritizing political games over governing effectively, betraying voters' trust and harming the middle class.

Australian singer Cody Simpson is promoting the U.N.'s International Day of Happiness on March 20 by performing at SXSW and serving as spokesman for the #HappySoundsLike playlist. He and other celebrities selected songs to spread happiness through music. Fans are encouraged to share their happy songs using #HappySoundsLike.

At the Gridiron Club dinner, President Obama joked about legalized marijuana in D.C. and Hillary Clinton's email controversy. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker also spoke, jesting about Obama's patriotism. Obama responded with a joke referencing birther conspiracies. The event, usually closed to media, allows for candid humor among attendees.

Chinese experts claim a 1,000-year-old mummified monk inside a Buddha statue, displayed in Europe, was stolen from a Chinese village temple in 1995. Discovered via CT scans, the relic's origins are under investigation as authorities seek its repatriation.

Penn State fraternity Kappa Delta Rho was suspended after allegations members posted compromising photos of women, some unconscious, on a private Facebook page. Police and university officials are investigating. President Eric Barron said they may reevaluate fraternities at Penn State due to the incident.

On March 25, 2015, CNN Student News covered the U.S. decision to maintain troop levels in Afghanistan, Israel denying spying on Iran negotiations, a passenger plane crash in the French Alps, and featured a CNN Hero helping youth with eye and ear health.

Parisa Tabriz, Google's "Security Princess," leads a team that hacks into Chrome to identify vulnerabilities before malicious hackers do. She promotes creativity in cybersecurity, addresses gender imbalance in tech, and protects users—including high-profile individuals—from evolving cyber threats and government surveillance by staying ahead of attackers.

An unknown group, 'Islamic State Hacking Division', posted personal details of 100 US troops online, urging attacks. They claim to have hacked military databases, but officials doubt the credibility, noting the info is publicly available. Authorities are investigating; military personnel advised to limit online personal information.

Serena Williams returned to Indian Wells in 2015 after a 14-year boycott following alleged racial abuse there in 2001. Receiving a warm welcome, she was moved by the crowd's support. Williams won her match, expressing that just being back was one of her proudest achievements.

Actor and martial artist Chuck Norris turns 75 on March 10. Known for humorous "Chuck Norris Facts" jokes—like "nobody crosses Chuck Norris and lives"—he celebrates his birthday, reminding us that while we can't beat time, he can beat anything.

Serena Williams is ending her 13-year boycott of the Indian Wells tournament, where she faced booing and alleged racism in 2001. After consulting her family, she chose to return in a spirit of forgiveness, aiming to show strength despite past hurt.

In 2015, Pi Day is extra special as 3/14/15 mirrors 3.1415. At 9:26:53 AM or PM, it aligns with even more digits of pi. Pi, the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter, is an irrational number known for 4,000 years. Pi Day began in 1988 at San Francisco's Exploratorium, with celebrations now held there and in Princeton, New Jersey, where Einstein lived.

Richard III's remains, found in 2012 under a Leicester car park, reveal he had scoliosis but not a hunchback; DNA shows he had blue eyes and blond hair. Bone analysis indicates his diet became richer as king, including exotic meats. Evidence of roundworm and battle injuries align with historical accounts.

Tom Hanks stars in Carly Rae Jepsen's music video for "I Really Like You," lip-syncing her vocals while playing himself. He suggested himself for the role after Jepsen thought it would be amusing for a man to lip-sync her song. Justin Bieber also makes an appearance.

Judge orders Pentagon to release photos of alleged detainee abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan, following ACLU lawsuit; government failed to prove release would endanger Americans. Pentagon has 60 days to appeal; ACLU argues disclosure helps public understand Bush-era policies.

Singer David Crosby accidentally hit a jogger with his car near his home in Santa Ynez, California. The jogger suffered non-life-threatening injuries. Crosby was driving within the speed limit, was not impaired, and attributed the accident to sun glare. He is upset and wishes the jogger a speedy recovery.

At Iraq's request, the U.S.-led coalition began airstrikes in Tikrit to support Iraqi forces aiming to retake the city from ISIS. The strikes target ISIS strongholds to aid Iraqi maneuvering and could pave the way for retaking Mosul. Previous attempts to recapture Tikrit since 2014 have failed.

Denise Huskins, 29, reported kidnapped from her boyfriend's Vallejo, California, home, was found safe in Huntington Beach. Police are treating it as a ransom kidnapping and are investigating all possibilities with FBI involvement. Huskins is in good condition, and the case remains under investigation.

Retired NFL star Darren Sharper pleaded guilty to sexual assault charges in Arizona and was sentenced to nine years in prison with no early release, plus lifetime probation. He faced multiple charges of drugging and raping women in several states and has been jailed in Los Angeles since last year.

Germanwings Flight 4U 9525 crashed after a controlled descent from cruising altitude without issuing a distress call. Experts suggest the pilot was still controlling the plane, possibly attempting an emergency landing in mountainous terrain. The black box was recovered, and investigations focus on the lack of communication and possible factors causing the crash.

The NIH will admit an American health care worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in Sierra Leone to its Maryland hospital on Friday. This will be the second Ebola patient treated there. Over 10,000 people have died in the Ebola outbreak, mainly in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone.

The VA is misinterpreting the Choice Act by denying veterans access to local healthcare if they live within 40 miles of any VA facility, even if that facility doesn't offer needed services. Legislation is proposed to fix this and ensure veterans can access care in their communities.

Angelina Jolie, 39, had her ovaries and fallopian tubes removed due to a BRCA1 gene mutation increasing her cancer risk. After a double mastectomy, she shared her experience in a New York Times op-ed, encouraging women to explore options and take control of their health.

The BBC suspended "Top Gear" host Jeremy Clarkson after a "fracas with a BBC producer," canceling Sunday's episode. Fans, dismayed, launched a petition for his reinstatement. Clarkson, known for controversies, previously apologized for using a racist term and faced backlash over a Falklands War reference in Argentina.

The Mormon Church, major sponsor of Boy Scout troops, asserts strong abuse prevention measures but faces allegations of failing to prevent sexual abuse. Notably, scoutmaster Hein, previously expelled for misconduct, was reinstated and abused Novak. Lawsuits were settled; Hein is imprisoned. Church leaders express regret for victims' suffering.

After a fan questioned why she revealed Albus Dumbledore is gay, J.K. Rowling replied that "gay people just look like... people," emphasizing that sexual orientation isn't always apparent. Her fans appreciated her response.

Vallejo police declared the reported kidnapping of Denise Huskins a hoax that wasted resources. Huskins and her boyfriend, Aaron Quinn, are no longer cooperating with authorities. The FBI is investigating, and charges may be filed. Police assured the community that there was no random act and they are safe.

Rohana Rozhan, once nicknamed "Rohana the Piranha," is the CEO of Astro Malaysia, a $4.6 billion media company. Known for her fierce independence, she leads a firm producing over 9,000 hours of content annually. Rozhan emphasizes merit and has a workforce that's 52% female.

Actor Jon Hamm, known for playing Don Draper on "Mad Men," completed a 30-day rehab for alcohol abuse with support from his partner Jennifer Westfeldt. His representatives confirmed the news and requested privacy. This comes shortly before the show's final episodes begin airing.

Pastor Creflo Dollar is seeking donations totaling over $60 million to buy a Gulfstream G650 jet for his ministry's global outreach, citing safety issues with his current 30-year-old plane. He asks 200,000 people to donate $300 or more to help purchase the luxury jet.

A new study reveals Neanderthals were more advanced than thought. Researchers found 130,000-year-old eagle talons in Croatia with cut marks, indicating Neanderthals made jewelry. This suggests they were sophisticated, capable of planning, and interested in ornamentation, challenging the stereotype of them as simple-minded.

University of Oklahoma students Parker Rice and Levi Pettit were expelled after leading a racist fraternity chant referencing lynching in a video. Both apologized; Rice called his actions wrong. Their families faced backlash, while friends defended them, saying the behavior doesn't reflect their true character.

An 11-year-old British boy dressed as Christian Grey from "Fifty Shades of Grey" for World Book Day, complete with cable ties and an eyemask. The school deemed the costume inappropriate and contacted his mother, who defended the choice, noting others dressed as violent characters. The school modified his costume.

A Washington driver was fined $124 for using a cardboard cutout of actor Jonathan Goldsmith, known as "The Most Interesting Man in the World," to illegally drive in the HOV lane. The trooper noticed the prop; the laughing driver was ticketed, and the incident was shared on social media, praising his creativity.

Storms and reported tornadoes swept across Oklahoma on Wednesday, killing one person and injuring about 24 others. A tornado destroyed a mobile home park in Sand Springs near Tulsa. Governor Mary Fallin declared a state of emergency for 25 counties. Severe weather also impacted Oklahoma City and Moore.

Republicans urge Congress to reverse Obama's defense cuts and sequestration to restore military strength amid growing threats from ISIS, Russia, and China. Underfunding has compromised readiness; they propose increasing defense budgets to previous levels to ensure security, fulfill federal responsibilities, and properly equip the military.

A massive winter storm stretching 2,000 miles from New Mexico to southern New England is affecting 94 million people with snow, sleet, and ice. Travel disruptions abound, federal offices are closed, and significant snowfall is expected, though Boston may not break its snowfall record despite nearing it.

During an eviction in Detroit, police discovered the bodies of a 14-year-old girl and an 11-year-old boy inside a freezer. The mother was arrested on child abuse charges, and two other children were placed in protective custody. Authorities are investigating and seeking public assistance.

Russian President Vladimir Putin reappeared publicly after a 10-day unexplained absence that fueled rumors about his health and grip on power. Meeting with Kyrgyz President Atambayev in St. Petersburg, Putin dismissed the speculation, saying, "It would be boring without gossip," aiming to quell the concerns.

Scientists propose that Jupiter's inward migration toward the sun destroyed early super-Earths in the inner solar system by sweeping planetesimals into the sun. This cleared space for smaller terrestrial planets—Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars—to form from remaining material after Jupiter moved back out due to Saturn's influence.

Two cousins in Illinois, including Army National Guard member Hasan Edmonds, were arrested for conspiring to support ISIS. Hasan planned to join ISIS overseas, while Jonas Edmonds plotted to attack a U.S. military facility in Illinois, using Hasan's uniform to cause mass casualties.

Jeremy Clarkson, host of BBC's "Top Gear," faced multiple controversies for offensive remarks and actions, including using racial slurs on air, making derogatory comments about Mexicans and northerners, and provoking anger in Argentina with a car's license plate referencing the Falklands War, leading to attacks on the crew.

A new biography, "Becoming Steve Jobs" by Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli, offers a kinder portrayal of Steve Jobs, focusing on his growth and softer edges in later years. Apple executives, including Tim Cook, endorse it over Walter Isaacson's earlier biography, though external reviews remain mixed.

Taraji P. Henson apologized for falsely claiming her son was racially profiled during a Glendale traffic stop. Dash cam footage contradicted his claims. Her son admitted to possessing marijuana and Ritalin without a prescription but was only cited for marijuana. Henson admitted overreacting and apologized to police.

CNN experts explained that the Germanwings co-pilot set a controlled descent to avoid alarms; planes lack auto-stop tech due to complexity; live cameras and remote control pose security risks; hacking is improbable; absence of explosion was due to crash dynamics; pilots have medical screenings but not frequent drug tests.

Gareth Bale scored twice and assisted once as Wales beat Israel 3-0 in Euro 2016 qualifying, moving top of their group and nearing their first major finals since 1958. Despite criticism in Spain, Bale excelled. Italy and the Czech Republic drew, while Iceland beat Kazakhstan 3-0.

Wait A Little horse safaris in South Africa offers horseback tours through game reserves, providing a closer wildlife experience than vehicle safaris. Owners Philip and Gerti Kusseler train ex-racehorses to navigate safely among lions and other animals, offering adventurous guests a unique but potentially risky safari option.

On the eve of Nigeria's elections, the military announced it recaptured Gwoza, which Boko Haram had declared their "caliphate" headquarters in 2014. President Goodluck Jonathan praised the victory. Boko Haram, which recently pledged allegiance to ISIS, has killed over 1,000 civilians this year and faces multinational military opposition.

Violent protests erupted in Nigeria's Rivers state over alleged election rigging by the opposition All Peoples Congress, which demands vote cancellations. The ruling Peoples Democratic Party denies the claims. Both presidential candidates urge calm as results are counted, fearing unrest if the outcome is disputed.

Italy's high court overturned the murder convictions of Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito in the 2007 killing of Meredith Kercher, definitively clearing them. The Kercher family is disappointed and may appeal to the European Court. Sollecito may sue Italy for false imprisonment. Knox expressed relief and gratitude.

Tropical Cyclone Pam devastated Vanuatu, destroying or damaging 90% of homes in the capital Port Vila and causing widespread destruction across the islands. At least 11 people are confirmed dead, with the toll expected to rise. Thousands are homeless, lacking food, water, and shelter, as aid efforts begin.

A bipartisan movement is uniting conservatives and progressives to reform the U.S. criminal justice system. Leaders from both parties will attend a summit co-produced by Gingrich Productions and Van Jones's #cut50, aiming to halve incarceration rates. They seek to address mass incarceration violating principles of liberty and justice for all.

Zayn Malik has left One Direction after five years, the band announced. Remaining members Niall, Harry, Liam, and Louis will continue as a four-piece. Fans reacted emotionally online, and streams of One Direction's music surged. Malik had recently left the tour amid stress-related issues following a scandal.

Zayn Malik apologized to fans after leaving One Direction, saying he felt unhappy and needed to be true to himself. He's maintaining good relations with the band and has started a solo project. One Direction will continue as a foursome, while fans express sadness and disbelief.

The first trailer for the James Bond film "SPECTRE" has been released, featuring Daniel Craig returning as Bond. Directed by Sam Mendes, the film follows Bond infiltrating a terrorist organization after a cryptic message from his past. The teaser hints at the plot with clues and introduces key characters.

Vladimir Putin's absence from public view sparked rumors about his health, with social media speculation and skepticism of official reassurances. The incident highlights Putin's dominance in Russia and raises questions about succession and the country's future without him.

Charlottesville Police found no evidence to support a University of Virginia student's claim, reported by Rolling Stone, that she was raped at a fraternity house. The investigation revealed discrepancies, and the magazine later apologized for not verifying the story with the accused parties.

Kylie Minogue will perform a 90-minute show at the 20th Dubai World Cup on March 28. The event, boasting $30 million in prizes, is the world's richest day of horse racing. Minogue expressed excitement, linking to her Melbourne roots where horse racing is significant.

Thousands in Tunisia protested against terrorism after the Bardo Museum attack that killed over 20 people. President Essebsi and global leaders marched to the museum, with banners like "We are not afraid." Authorities said Khaled Shayeb, alleged mastermind, was killed in a raid before the protest.

Michael Ibsen, a descendant of Richard III, crafted a coffin for the king's reburial after his remains were found under a Leicester car park in 2012. The discovery led to a reassessment of Richard's legacy. Ceremonies will honor him, aiming to rectify historical mistreatment and make peace with history.

After Sen. Harry Reid announced his retirement and endorsed Chuck Schumer as his successor, Schumer is poised to become Senate Democratic leader despite opposition from progressives favoring Elizabeth Warren. With strong political skills, significant fundraising, and Reid's backing, Schumer's long-term ambition and media savvy position him to lead the party.

Seven college-age people, including Alabama A&M students aged 20-22, were wounded in a shooting during spring break in Panama City Beach, Florida. Suspect David Daniels, 22, was arrested for attempted murder. The incident was among six firearms-related events that night, prompting officials to discuss increased enforcement.

A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday, killing all 150 aboard. The plane from Barcelona to Düsseldorf lost altitude for eight minutes before impact. Among the victims were 16 German students. Recovery is hampered by remote terrain; one black box has been recovered.

AMC's "The Walking Dead" companion series is titled "Fear The Walking Dead," as announced by Robert Kirkman. It’s a prequel set in Los Angeles at the onset of the zombie outbreak, featuring new characters. The series premieres in late summer, with season two slated for 2016.

Kentucky crushed West Virginia 78-39 to remain unbeaten at 37-0 in the NCAA men's basketball tournament. Notre Dame defeated Wichita State 81-70, Wisconsin edged North Carolina 79-72, and Arizona beat Xavier 68-60. Arizona will face Wisconsin next, while Kentucky continues as the dominant team to watch.

Lewis Hamilton secured pole position for the Malaysian Grand Prix amid torrential conditions, beating Sebastian Vettel and Nico Rosberg, who finished second and third respectively. Qualifying was delayed by thunderstorms. Seventeen-year-old Max Verstappen impressed by qualifying sixth in only his second Formula One race.

Yemen's President Hadi met with regional leaders in Egypt as Saudi-led airstrikes intensified against Houthi rebels in Sana'a. The Arab League considered endorsing the operation, potentially enabling a ground invasion. Civilian casualties increased, and media outlets were targeted amid the escalating conflict between Sunni nations and Iran-aligned Houthis.

A commuter train collided with a car and derailed near USC in Los Angeles, injuring 21 people, including one critically and one gravely. The accident occurred when a car turned onto the tracks; the derailment may affect traffic for a soccer game at the nearby LA Memorial Coliseum.

Germanwings Flight 9525 crashed into the Alps after co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately initiated the aircraft's descent while the pilot was out of the cockpit. All 150 on board died instantly. Passengers likely noticed the unexpected descent and the pilot's failed attempts to re-enter the cockpit.

Nearly a million fans petitioned for Jeremy Clarkson's reinstatement after his suspension from BBC's "Top Gear" for allegedly hitting a producer. Supporters delivered the petition via tank to BBC headquarters. Clarkson hinted he may not return, while Prime Minister David Cameron expressed hope for a resolution.

The community of Montoursville, Pennsylvania, offers heartfelt condolences to Haltern am See, Germany, after the loss of 16 students and two teachers in a plane crash. Having endured a similar tragedy 19 years ago, they share their experiences to support and comfort those grieving.

The article reflects on Andreas Lubitz, the Germanwings co-pilot who deliberately crashed a plane. It challenges the perception of pilots as infallible professionals, emphasizing that they are human and prone to flaws. Thus, catastrophic acts, though rare, can occur, and we shouldn't be overly astonished when they do.

On March 30, 2015, CNN Student News covered Nigeria's elections, an astronaut's 340-day mission becoming an experiment on the ISS, and an invention using low-frequency sound to extinguish fires. Viewers can access the show's transcript and request their school to be mentioned on the CNN Student News Roll Call.

Manchester United boosted their Champions League hopes by beating Tottenham 3-0 with goals from Fellaini, Carrick, and Rooney, who celebrated by mocking a viral boxing video. Chelsea drew 1-1 with Southampton but extended their EPL lead. Real Madrid beat Levante 2-0 with two goals from Gareth Bale.

Singaporeans gathered in rain Sunday to bid farewell to Lee Kuan Yew, founding PM who led its economic rise. Global leaders attended the funeral where his son, PM Lee Hsien Loong, gave a eulogy. Though admired, Lee was criticized for restricting civil liberties, and Human Rights Watch called for reforms.

Houthi rebels seized Yemen's Taiz airport, intensifying conflict as the UN warns the nation is on the edge of civil war. Clashes have killed civilians, and President Hadi disputes his resignation. The UN urges dialogue, but violence persists amid fears of ISIS and al Qaeda exploiting the chaos.

After a video showed University of Oklahoma fraternity members chanting racist slurs, another surfaced of their house mother, Beauton Gilbow, repeatedly using a racial epithet in a rap song. Gilbow denies being racist, and two black alumni defend her character. The Sigma Alpha Epsilon chapter was closed, and two students were expelled.

Marine biologists at the South Carolina Aquarium are treating Yawkey, a rare 475-pound juvenile leatherback sea turtle—the first such rescue in the state and fifth in the U.S. After recovering from hypoglycemia, they plan to release it soon, as leatherbacks don't thrive in captivity.

ISIS claimed responsibility for an attack on the Bardo Museum in Tunis, where gunmen killed 23 people, mostly foreign tourists. The attackers were killed by security forces. The incident raises concerns about ISIS influence in Tunisia and its impact on the country's vital tourism industry.

World powers and Iran intensified nuclear talks ahead of a Tuesday deadline but remain divided over limits on Iran's nuclear research and the pace of lifting UN sanctions. Israeli PM Netanyahu warned the emerging deal is dangerous. Key issues include centrifuge limits and sanction relief timing.

A California jury ruled that Robin Thicke's and Pharrell Williams' "Blurred Lines" infringed on Marvin Gaye's "Got to Give It Up," awarding the Gaye family over $7 million. This landmark case emphasizes that artistic inspiration can cross into copyright infringement in the music industry.

Over half the world's population now lives in cities, with urbanization driving growth, particularly in Africa. PwC's report ranks African cities: North African cities like Cairo lead in infrastructure and human capital, while sub-Saharan cities like Dar es Salaam lead in investment potential, signaling emerging economic powerhouses.

Comedian Trevor Noah will replace Jon Stewart as host of "The Daily Show," it was announced Monday. Noah, a 31-year-old South African who debuted on the show in December, expressed excitement about the role. Stewart, who hosted for 16 years, approves of his replacement.

In Nigeria, "free readers associations" are groups where mostly young men gather at newspaper stands to read headlines and debate without buying papers. Vendors welcome them, charging small fees. However, readership is declining due to internet news and economic hardships, highlighting Nigeria's wealth inequality.

India's Supreme Court declared Section 66A of the 2008 Information Technology Act unconstitutional, overturning a law that allowed authorities to arrest people for online comments deemed offensive or annoying, thereby upholding freedom of expression.

Three Los Angeles residents were arrested for operating four sham schools that issued student visas to 1,500 foreign students who didn't attend classes. They collected up to $6 million annually in a "pay-to-stay" immigration fraud scheme. Charges include conspiracy, immigration fraud, and money laundering.

The Duchess of Cambridge, Catherine, made her final public appearances before giving birth in April. She and Prince William visited London's Stephen Lawrence Centre and a youth charity. This will be their second child; their son, Prince George, was born in July 2013.

The article examines the Germanwings Flight 9525 tragedy where co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed the plane. It highlights the challenges of predicting such events due to human unpredictability, advocates for rigorous psychological screening of pilots, and notes that human factors often cause anomalies in complex systems.

Director Sam Taylor-Johnson announced she won't return for the "Fifty Shades of Grey" sequels. Despite the first film's success, grossing over $550 million worldwide, creative differences with author E L James—who wants to write the next screenplay—may have influenced her decision.

Despite dislocating his shoulder in December, 85-year-old golf legend Arnold Palmer vows to hit the ceremonial opening tee shot at the Masters in April. Although doctors haven't allowed him to swing yet, he insists he'll join Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player on the course.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani stated that a nuclear deal is achievable, though details remain challenging. Talks in Switzerland have made progress ahead of the March 31 deadline, but key issues like sanctions relief persist. The P5+1 nations seek a deal ensuring Iran's nuclear program is peaceful.

In rural China, 61 million "left-behind" children like Lu Yiming grow up without parents who migrate for work. Due to the hukou system restricting services in cities, parents leave children behind, causing social, educational, and behavioral issues among these unattended children.

Afghan President Ghani's U.S. visit sparks hope for peace talks with the Taliban, but major challenges make success unlikely now. The U.S. should support by slowing troop withdrawals and aiding Afghanistan's government to strengthen its legitimacy and ability to enforce future agreements.

Iraqi forces, supported by Shia militias and U.S.-led airstrikes, have captured key areas of Tikrit from ISIS, raising the Iraqi flag over important buildings. After clearing over 300 improvised explosive devices, they liberated neighborhoods in southern Tikrit, killing at least 26 militants.

Hillary Clinton faces controversy for using a private email account and server as Secretary of State, raising questions about transparency and regulation violations. Drawing on her history of surviving scandals, she is expected to employ familiar tactics to counterattack and rally her base.

Swedish prosecutors asked Julian Assange to consent to an interview in London over 2010 sexual assault allegations, due to an impending statute of limitations. Assange, residing in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London since 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden, views the request positively.

New Zealand reached their first Cricket World Cup final after defeating South Africa in a thrilling semifinal in Auckland. Chasing a revised target of 298 in 43 overs due to rain, Grant Elliott's unbeaten 84, including a six off the penultimate ball, secured victory.

An increasing number of young Chinese are embracing Buddhism, especially Tibetan Buddhism, seeking spiritual comfort and stress relief in a fast-changing society. While some consider becoming monks, many treat Buddhism culturally, focusing on meditation and volunteering rather than strict religious commitment.

An explosive-laden truck detonated at an Egyptian security forces camp in Al-Arish, North Sinai, killing the driver and a civilian, and injuring 44 people (42 soldiers, 2 civilians). Guards shot at the truck as it approached the gate. No group has claimed responsibility.

Al-Shabaab militants attacked government offices in Baidoa, Somalia, killing nine people, including four attackers. They targeted regional president Sharif Hassan Sheikh Aden's residence with a car bomb and gunfire. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility. The African Union condemned the attack as a desperate move after recent defeats.

Canadian tennis player Eugenie Bouchard teamed up with Justin Bieber for a charity tennis match at the Desert Smash event in California. Bouchard praised Bieber's serve on Twitter. Caroline Wozniacki also shared a photo with the singer during the event.

Despite progress in Iran nuclear talks, Israel opposes any deal but is unlikely to strike Iran militarily due to severe political, diplomatic, and security consequences, including international backlash and retaliation. Instead, Israel will likely criticize the agreement, lobby against it, and push for continued sanctions and monitoring.

Kenya, the world's third-largest exporter of cut flowers, supplies 35% of the EU market due to its favorable climate and transport links. The industry supports over 500,000 people. Despite environmental concerns, mitigation efforts are underway. Kenya is expanding into new markets and aiding Rwanda's floriculture sector.

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson hosted "SNL," featuring sketches like a "Bambi" remake with "Fast and Furious" actors and "The Rock Obama." He spoofed WWE, then appeared at Wrestlemania 31 with Ronda Rousey to confront WWE executives. He is the son of Rocky Johnson and wrestled as "The Rock" before acting.

Approximately 150 homeless people were given a special tour of Vatican City, including the Vatican Museums and Sistine Chapel, organized by the Office of Papal Charities. Led by Archbishop Konrad Krajewski, the visit allowed them to experience the Vatican's artistic heritage beyond the steps of St. Peter's Square.

Britain's Supreme Court ruled that Prince Charles's secret letters to government officials must be published, overturning the government's veto. The Guardian fought since 2005 to release them, believing they reveal Charles's political influence. The decision raises concerns about his neutrality as future king and his role in politics.

The article discusses tiger conservation in India, highlighting that human-tiger conflicts pose a greater threat than poaching. Efforts in conflict mediation have led to a 30% increase in tiger numbers, but rapid human population growth challenges coexistence with these apex predators on an increasingly crowded planet.

Indiana's RFRA, signed by Gov. Pence, caused an uproar over fears it allows discrimination against LGBT people. While Pence denies this, potential fixes include statewide nondiscrimination laws or amending RFRA to protect LGBT rights, but chances are slim, revealing the law's true intent to permit discrimination.

Jordan Spieth won the Valspar Championship in a playoff, becoming the fourth player since 1940 to win twice on the PGA Tour before turning 22. He aims to surpass Rory McIlroy as world No.1, viewing this victory as a key step toward that goal.

On April 1, 2015, CNN Student News features global events from Nigeria, Switzerland, and West Africa, examines how U.S. wages are affecting the economy at the start of Financial Literacy Month, and explores the ethics, debate, and science behind using cyborg cockroaches as potential rescuers.

Lewis Hamilton won the Australian Grand Prix, leading a Mercedes one-two with Nico Rosberg second. Sebastian Vettel was third for Ferrari. Only 11 cars finished from a grid of 15. Notable retirements included Kimi Raikkonen and Max Verstappen. Felipe Nasr impressed with fifth for Sauber. Arnold Schwarzenegger conducted podium interviews.

Michael Douglas wrote about his son Dylan's encounter with anti-Semitism when a man insulted him for wearing a Star of David. Douglas discusses rising anti-Semitism and urges society to confront it, emphasizing the need for collective action to combat such hatred.

Researchers recreated a 1,000-year-old Anglo-Saxon remedy from "Bald's Leechbook" using garlic, onion, wine, and cow bile. They found it killed up to 90% of MRSA bacteria, surprising scientists and suggesting medieval medicine was more advanced than thought, with potential implications for new antibiotic developments.

After re-election, Netanyahu reversed his stance against a Palestinian state, expressing support for a demilitarized two-state solution. Palestinian negotiator Erekat remains skeptical, planning to seek statehood through international means. The U.S. is reassessing its relationship with Israel as peace talks remain stalled amid mutual distrust.

Indiana's new "religious freedom" law, signed by Gov. Mike Pence, allows businesses to refuse service to gay and lesbian customers based on religious beliefs. Supporters claim it protects religious rights, while opponents view it as legalized discrimination. The law has sparked heated debate and calls for boycotts on social media.

London's Trafalgar Square unveiled "Gift Horse," a skeletal horse sculpture by Hans Haacke, on the Fourth Plinth. Featuring a ticker displaying live stock data, it comments on art, power, and money. Unveiled by Mayor Boris Johnson, it continues the plinth's tradition of provocative art, eliciting mixed public reactions.

Adam West and Burt Ward announced they will reprise their roles as Batman and Robin in an upcoming animated feature celebrating the 50th anniversary of the 1960s TV series in 2016. The project may include one or two 90-minute movies, though Warner Bros. declined to comment.

Negotiators in Switzerland extended talks on Iran's nuclear program by a day due to progress but unresolved issues. Key sticking points include sanctions relief, Iran's nuclear material stockpile, and nuclear technology limits. Optimism exists, but disagreements and opposition from Israel and some U.S. politicians persist.

BBC director-general Tony Hall received death threats via email after dismissing "Top Gear" host Jeremy Clarkson following an altercation with a producer. Police are investigating the threats, which appear to originate outside the UK. Over a million fans had petitioned for Clarkson's reinstatement.

Maria Shriver highlights the profound impact of Alzheimer's, particularly on women who are disproportionately affected as patients and caregivers. Inspired by "Still Alice," she launched the Wipe Out Alzheimer's Challenge to mobilize women to raise awareness, fund research, and change the narrative to make the disease understood, preventable, and treatable.

A Canadian tourist, 35-year-old Jennifer Karren from Calgary, died after a tour boat collided with a whale off Cabo San Lucas, Mexico. The inflatable boat, carrying nine people, was returning from a snorkel tour when it hit the whale. Despite receiving CPR, Karren was pronounced dead at the hospital.

Simone Gbagbo, former first lady of Ivory Coast, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for crimes against humanity linked to the 2010 post-election violence that left over 3,000 dead. Her husband, ex-President Laurent Gbagbo, awaits trial at the International Criminal Court on similar charges.
